channel.title: Business - Digg
channel.description: Business on Digg: the best articles, videos, tweets, and original content that the web is talking about right now

item.title: How Should Airlines Change Post-Pandemic?
item.description: Let's think big: how would you create the ideal flying experience? What drives you crazy about flying and what do you never want to deal with again?

item.title: How Coronavirus Affects America's Coffee Shops
item.description: If you compare the situation to the ongoing restaurant apocalypse, there's some hopeful news coming out of the coffee landscape.
item.kicker: YOU'LL GET BACK TO OVERPAYING FOR THE BEVERAGE

item.title: The Crash Of The $8.5 Billion Global Flower Trade
item.description: As people everywhere cancel events and big cut-flower orders, the ripples reach into Dutch auction halls and Kenyan rose fields.

item.title: Take YouTube's Dangers Seriously
item.description: The website's features can lead people unwittingly to scary places.

item.title: Dark Patterns Could Keep You From Getting Your Stimulus Check
item.description: The IRS enlisted TurboTax's help to deliver stimulus checks. It could cost you.
item.kicker: YOU'RE NOT PART OF THE TURBO TEAM

item.title: Whole Foods Is Quietly Tracking Its Employees With A Heat Map Tool That Ranks Which Stores Are Most At Risk Of Unionizing
item.description: Amazon-owned Whole Foods is quietly tracking its employees with a heat map tool that ranks which stores are most at risk of unionizing

item.title: Shake Shack Returning $10 Million Government Loan Meant For Small Businesses
item.description: With the Paycheck Protection Program already out of money, the burger chain says other restaurateurs need its loan more than it does.

item.title: Everyone Is Baking — And Entrepreneurs Are Rising Up To Meet The Demand
item.description: A look behind the numbers driving the latest quarantine craze and the small businesses that are filling a gap in the market.

item.title: Why Infiniti Is On The Verge Of Total Collapse
item.description: Doug DeMuro explains why the luxury car brand is on its way out of business.

item.title: The Subtle Ways Amazon Is Discouraging People From Ordering So Much Stuff
item.description: Strained by the pandemic, Amazon is now discouraging people from buying so much stuff.

item.title: Costco Is Thriving During The Coronavirus Pandemic. Its Workers Say They've Paid The Price
item.description: Costco has long been beloved by employees, some of whom have worked there for decades. But the retailer's decision-making during the coronavirus pandemic has tested their loyalty and compromised their health.

item.title: How To Save The Post Office In A Pandemic
item.description: Schemes to privatize the US Postal Service are being debated anew as coronavirus lockdowns drive mail volume down. But there's an equally radical alternative.

item.title: Hollywood Is All But Writing Off 2020. What Does That Mean For The Future Of Movies?
item.description: The studio executives and talent agents responsible for keeping the business part of showbiz beating ever forward against the tide have referred to the worldwide pandemic as "nuclear winter." "Doomsday," even.

item.title: 'We Went From $85 Million To $0 Overnight'
item.description: The CEO of Baltimore-based Atlas Restaurant Group on operating his 15-restaurant group in a new reality

item.title: Prepare For The Ultimate Gaslighting
item.description: What is about to be unleashed on American society will be the greatest campaign ever created to get you to feel normal again.

item.title: An Animated Chart Of The Biggest Fast Food Franchises In The World In The Past 50 Years
item.description: In the world of fast food chains, which franchise reigns supreme when it comes to the number of stores worldwide?

item.title: The Woman Who Is Remaking AMC
item.description: "The least safe thing to do is something safe," says Sarah Barnett, the unconventional TV executive behind "Killing Eve," which is back for a third season.

item.title: Some Companies Deserve To Fail
item.description: Why we shouldn't bail out the airlines and cruise companies.

item.title: I Run A Butcher Shop In Small-Town Pennsylvania. COVID-19 Has Transformed My Business — Possibly Forever
item.description: We used to be a place where our community gathered. Our approach has changed in ways we never could have imagined.

item.title: Trump's New Auto Rollback Is An Economic Disaster
item.description: According to the administration's own math, the pollution rules could eliminate jobs, discourage driving, and inflict billions in damage.

item.title: Unlike Patagonia, Everlane And Other Superficial 'Mission-Driven' Companies Won't Survive The Recession
item.description: If you can't uphold that mission when it really counts, how much of a strategic misfire was declaring it in the first place?

item.title: Job Interview Tips For A Post-Coronavirus World
item.description: After the coronavirus, job protection will be on the minds of every worker. Use the following job interview tips to find out how a company really treated its workers during the pandemic.

item.title: Bob Iger Thought He Was Leaving On Top. Now, He's Fighting For Disney's Life
item.description: The former CEO thought he was riding into the sunset. Now he's reasserting control and reimagining Disney as a company with fewer employees and more thermometers.

item.title: How Small Business Owners Survived The Great Recession
item.description: As COVID-19 rattles small businesses around the country, inspiration can be drawn from the stories of those who survived the last financial crisis.

item.title: CSA And Local Produce Demands Are Skyrocketing, But Farmers Can't Keep Up
item.description: Farmers can't keep up with surging demand for local produce, but they're still struggling to replace lost revenue.

item.title: What The Hell Is Going On At Trader Joe's?
item.description: For fans of the cult-favorite grocer, the current furor surrounding Trader Joe's and its workers may be surprising.

item.title: Companies Don't Need To Lay People Off To Survive
item.description: How one CEO saved his 12,000-person company without a single layoff.

item.title: A Long Time Until The Economic New Normal
item.description: Leaders must learn from the pandemic now to position their companies to thrive in the next crisis.

item.title: How To Build A Post-Cable TV Network From Quarantine
item.description: Shut out of one of its studios, gaming TV network Venn is fast-tracking its launch with a remote workforce.

item.title: Food Is No Longer Your Fallback Job. It Never Should Have Been In The First Place
item.description: There is no such thing as a "bad" job, just bad working conditions — and the coronavirus crisis should be our call to action to fix that.

item.title: Zoom Is Suddenly Critical Infrastructure. No One Is More Surprised Than Zoom
item.description: Eric Yuan built a tech unicorn in the unflashy business of enterprise communications. Then, suddenly, the world needed it to be something else.

item.title: The 1930s Depression Was 'Great.' This One Might Be Greater
item.description: When the pandemic ends, it could take five years before economic output gets back to where it was in February, warns a Stanford economics expert.

item.title: Cruise Lines Are Getting Desperate
item.description: Cruises were a dubious proposition before coronavirus, but now they're in far worse shape. Almost everywhere cruise lines look these days, the news isn't good.

item.title: The Saga Of Punkin' Donuts
item.description: How a doughnut-shop parking lot became a confluence of Chicago youth subcultures — and what killed it off.

item.title: Winery Launches Dog Delivery Service
item.description: A winery in Maryland launched a new curbside dog delivery service, in which a dog named Soda Pup will bring a maximum of two wine bottles to your car.
item.kicker: CAN THEY DELIVER TO ALL 50 STATES

item.title: The Truth About Empty Shelves And Toilet Paper Shortages
item.description: The sudden shift in the way Americans shop is stunning.

item.title: Elon Musk's Billionaire Brother Told His Workers They Were Family. Until COVID-19 Hit
item.description: Workers at Kimbal Musk's Next Door had something called the Family Fund, a pool of money they contributed to out of their paychecks, for use in times of crisis. Then a crisis hit. And the Family Fund wasn't there for them at all.

item.title: Silicon Valley's Newest Obsession: An Anonymously Created 'Hot Guys Of Tech' List
item.description: The 15-person ranking is entertaining the nation's technorati who are eagerly browsing the list, debating its selections and staring at it in bemused horror.

item.title: Should You Put Your Job Search On Hold?
item.description: Companies have halted their hiring processes, unemployment claims have skyrocketed and people navigating their state's unemployment systems right now deserve medals for their patience.

item.title: The Risks Of Relying On Mark Zuckerberg And Bill Gates In The Coronavirus Crisis
item.description: This crisis has us living in tech billionaires' world now more than ever.

item.title: Gem Fatale: The Frenzied Hustle Of The Jewelry Business
item.description: "All small-time hustlers living beyond their means are gamblers."

item.title: Amazon's Curious, Shifting Definition Of What Is 'Essential'
item.description: Currently that appears to include a 10-pack of rubber chickens

item.title: It's Now Amazon's Turn In The Spotlight
item.description: The tech superpower faces hard questions over how it's handling worker safety.
item.kicker: GOT OUR EYES ON YOU, BEZOS

item.title: 'It Was Gone Overnight': One Restaurant's Struggle To Weather The Pandemic
item.description: Eric Wang first noticed something was wrong on March 9.

item.title: Why Quibi Will Be A Multi-Billion Dollar Company
item.description: Short-form premium video is here to stay.

item.title: Meet Rocco. He Owns A Dairy Queen. The Government's Flawed Coronavirus Plan Might Not Save It
item.description: Why the small-business rescue isn't going to rescue some businesses.

item.title: Big Employers Used Arbitration Clauses To Stave Off Lawsuits. Now The System Is Being Turned Against Them
item.description: Lawyers and a Silicon Valley start-up have found ways to flood the system with claims, so companies are looking to thwart a process they created.

item.title: Nike's Secret For Surviving The Retail Apocalypse
item.description: Why struggling retailers should be studying Nike's pandemic strategy in China.

item.title: What Exactly Is A Furlough?
item.description: Macy's, the Gap and other retailers are furloughing a majority of their workers amid the coronavirus pandemic. What exactly is a furlough?

item.title: Airbnb, After Coronavirus
item.description: The short-term rental market is reeling from the coronavirus-driven tourism collapse. Can the industry's dominant player stage a comeback after lockdowns lift?
